text:
Following!!

We have an external roadmap that isn’t just freely available but our customers and prospects have access to it :slightly_smiling_face:

We also use <https://headwayapp.co/|Headway> to share all of our product updates, but externally, only the odd product update LinkedIn post linking to this from our company profile directs non-client traffic here. But I suppose you could make it public. :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
in my experience, product updates/announcements on the blog convert really well. sometimes people are waiting to buy until you have a specific feature.

if blog audience is so different than product audience that they're not at all interested, that sounds like it's the wrong audience to me. but maybe i'm just not understanding.

text:
Depends on the context. I think it's generally a good idea if it's done well, but is more often than not done poorly.

If the blog has a true "audience," that audience should be relevant to the product. If the blog has "traffic" (but not an "audience" per se), then it doesn't much matter if something different from the typical content goes up there.

text: If your content strategy includes survey-based reports and/or original research (industry benchmarks, state of the _____, etc.), who have you used to run the survey and/or analyze the data? Gearing up for our annual survey project and seeking to "buy" and not "build" this year. Any suggestions?

elements.text: If your content strategy includes survey-based reports and/or original research (industry benchmarks, state of the _____, etc.), who have you used to run the survey and/or analyze the data? Gearing up for our annual survey project and seeking to "buy" and not "build" this year. Any suggestions?

text:
My answer would be industry-specific. If I'm doing a Microsoft Teams report, I'd only use a Microsoft consultancy or analysis firm.

However, these are usually super expensive so a big in-house fan here :heart:

elements.text:
My answer would be industry-specific. If I'm doing a Microsoft Teams report, I'd only use a Microsoft consultancy or analysis firm.

However, these are usually super expensive so a big in-house fan here

text: Yeah, 100% agree with the subject matter expertise being important. Fortunately, I'm in a very "horizontal" category now, so I think nearly any firm could execute the work so long as the survey design and analysis plan are sound.

elements.text: Yeah, 100% agree with the subject matter expertise being important. Fortunately, I'm in a very "horizontal" category now, so I think nearly any firm could execute the work so long as the survey design and analysis plan are sound.

text: Thanks <@UU07F98SJ>, I will check them out. In a past life, I got project estimates from Ponemon Institute (they do IBM's Cost of a Data Breach annual research - literally my fav annual report, <https://www.ponemon.org/>) and Zogby (<https://zogbyanalytics.com/>), and was impressed.

attachments.title: Home | Ponemon Institute
attachments.text: Ponemon is dedicated to independent research & education that advances the responsible use of information and privacy management practices within business and government.

attachments.title: Zogby Analytics | President Biden Surveys & Approval Ratings
attachments.text: Zogby Analytics provides custom research and insight to leaders of businesses and communities, as well as to individuals. We will empower you to reach your most pressing survey research goals. Whether you need results right away, or you need help determining your research objectives, Zogby Analytics will help. We have the experience and the tools to bring you the most reliable research-based solutions. Based on our four decades of Independent polling and research, our advanced data collection and analysis will deliver you the data you need. Whether you are polling nationally in the US, or worldwide in difficult to reach areas such as the Middle East, we have the experience to make your project a success. Our staff is composed entirely of senior level executives from Zogby International, as such we bring our many years of reliable research experience to work for you. Whether you need telephone research, social media tracking, an interactive study, or some combination, we are prepared to help you achieve your goals.
attachments.fallback: Zogby Analytics | President Biden Surveys & Approval Ratings

text: Did you use their panel feature to buy responses or just create the survey using SurveyMonkey? I had some issues with respondents at first but the Audience team helped me relaunch my survey and once it was formatted better I didn’t have any issues. I just used their full-time employee panel though so I didn’t have a hard time finding responses.

text: I think product blog announcements do well when they focus on solving a problem or meeting a need for the audience. They should scream, "We get you, and we're always making [Product] better because we get you." If you can't do that, it shouldn't be a blog post, which is more TOFU-facing. Engineers self-congratulating on technical features no one cares about, copy-and-paste press releases, or CEO-centering should be an automatic nope.

elements.text: I think product blog announcements do well when they focus on solving a problem or meeting a need for the audience. They should scream, "We get you, and we're always making [Product] better because we get you." If you can't do that, it shouldn't be a blog post, which is more TOFU-facing. Engineers self-congratulating on technical features no one cares about, copy-and-paste press releases, or CEO-centering should be an automatic nope.

text:
Does anyone have any great examples of *before-and-after case studies*? Or any thoughts or opinions on this content type?

My current project is to rework my brand's series of results-focused blog posts into something more cohesive to improve conversion rates. We currently have a hot mess of super casual copy pulled straight from actual customer emails, poor quality UGC, and non-optimized missives from a prior owner who had zero SEO knowledge, yet these posts are still getting traffic and conversions. We have a wealth of great UGC (largely thanks to implementing Okendo reviews last year!) and a catalog of products that actually do work with results which show up easily in photos, and we know based on advertising data that this type of content definitely converts. This is in the pet care industry, specifically canine skin and coat health. TIA for any input or inspiration!

<@U02AW1ZR5AB> and I are looking for some advanced tips and strategy on building and nurturing an email list for <http://MessageDesk.com|MessageDesk.com> via blog subscribe etc. Specifically, we're B2B SaaS trying to nurture local service businesses (housekeepers, plumbers, landscapers etc.)

What's the secret sauce for getting some real click-throughs and true content engagement? Any and all help/resources appreciated!

elements.text: and I are looking for some advanced tips and strategy on building and nurturing an email list for
MessageDesk.com

via blog subscribe etc. Specifically, we're B2B SaaS trying to nurture local service businesses (housekeepers, plumbers, landscapers etc.)

What's the secret sauce for getting some real click-throughs and true content engagement? Any and all help/resources appreciated!

text:
The best sequence is usually 5 emails. Think of the customer journey when creating the sequence to make it valuable to them. I usually start with a thought leadership/industry article article that talks about a trend or has statistics or great tips. You don't want to lead with your own content in the first email. Always provide value. Second and third emails should be around assets that address their key pain points. Then in 4th and 5th email is when you get into customer testimonials, long-form assets you've created and the last email should be a conversion CTA.

For engagement, A/B test subject lines. Two of my favorite formats to test are questions and [Asset type] Subject

And of course, one CTA per email.

Hope that helps.

elements.text:

Then in 4th and 5th email is when you get into customer testimonials, long-form assets you've created and the last email should be a conversion CTA.

And of course, one CTA per email.

Hope that helps.

text:
*Google Analytics + GSC question:* _How do you keep track of historical data when URLs change?_ 

I’ll restructure a good amount of our content, which also meant consolidating some content and/or changing URLs. Ideally I’d love to tie the historical data (e.g. GSC queries, clicks, impressions, avg position, CTR) to the new content, as well as GA traffic and goal conversion data. I used to export data into spreadsheets, and later dig in when evaluating impact, but don’t feel that’s a good use of my time anymore. Curious to how others handle this :slightly_smiling_face:
